awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Enhanced Robust Persistent Identification of Data (E-RPID)
awd_abstract_narration:
An increasing challenge in modern research is the rapid growth in ability to collect and store research data; this growth is much more rapid than the ability to catalog, make accessible, and reuse these data. Major challenges facing the scientific research enterprise include making data discoverable, accessible, and re-usable at Internet scales; and making it possible to use data to replicate analyses done in published research. The importance of this issue is at the center of many recent initiatives in Open Science and Open Data. The objective of this project is to address these deficiencies and to enable more options for data interoperability and reusability in the current research data landscape. One aim is to demonstrate how technical solutions for data accessibility and management should be designed, implemented, operated, and usable by a broad range of researchers. Another aim is to ultimately increase the publication, discovery, and reuse of data, thus contributing to the greater integrity of the scientific enterprise.

This project aims to create a full implementation of the Digital Object Architecture (DOA) concept to improve data interoperability and reusability and potentially transform the way research in many disciplines is conducted. The approach is to integrate existing and new software components into the Robust Persistent Identification of Data (RPID) testbed which itself is a 2-year pilot project supported by NSF (Project ID 1659310). Components to be added include a Digital Object Interface Protocol (DOIP) which defines common operations performed on digital objects; and a Repository Mapping Service which would allow mapping the contents of existing repositories to the Digital Object Architecture (DOA) environment. With the new components, the ensemble "Enhanced-RPID" (E-RPID) testbed will allow managing of data objects by assigning individual identifiers toward making data FAIR (findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable). This technical effort along with planned educational material are designed to lower the barrier for adoption of Persistent Identification (PID)-centric data management throughout the data lifecycle, from initial data collection to long-term use and reuse. The E-RPID testbed will be housed on the NSF-funded Jetstream computational resource, will be applied to a number of important scientific use cases, and will contribute to activities fostered by the Research Data Alliance (RDA).  The outcomes of this project are aimed to broadly benefit disciplinary and multi-disciplinary research and to facilitate better access to and utilization of existing data repositories.

This project is supported by the National Science Foundation's Public Access Initiative which is managed by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure on behalf of the Foundation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Enhanced Robust Persistent Identification of Data (ERPID) project created and evaluated a pioneering testbed implementation of the Digital Object Architecture (DOA), creating prototype services that can be used to support more findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable (FAIR) scientific research. ERPID continued the work of the previous Robust Persistent Identification of Data (RPID) work (NSF #1659310). 

The ERPID testbed services consisted of a handle service responsible for issuing Persistent Identifiers (PIDs) and resolving state metadata about digital objects. It also provided a Data Type Registry (DTR) responsible for typing the state data held in the handle service. This typing information is at the core of creating machine actionable data management. Finally, a mapping service (designed for this project) was responsible for mapping existing data repository schemas to the DOA. This mapping allowed the Digital Object Interface Protocol (DOIP) to operate on the digital objects defined by PIDs with state metadata (in the handle service) based on the metadata description in the DTR. 

The ERPID project had three main goals; 1) developing software to map existing data repositories to Digital Objects, 2) testing the DOIP with real-world use cases, and 3) delivering introductory education sessions to familiarize the data sharing and cyberinfrastructure communities with the DOA, FAIR, and the ERPID testbed. 

To meet the project's goals, the testbed was transitioned to a cloud environment (the XSEDE Jetstream system, an OpenStack-based computing cloud), emphasizing the ease of reproducibility of the testbed components. The underlying software was updated to include the DOIP, and a mapping service was created using the Cordra software stack as a base. With the mapping service and protocol in place, protocol operations were tested and found to be sufficient to do the base CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, and Delete). This testing completed the first two goals of the project. 

The ERPID testbed was integrated with several real-world workflows in rice genomics, weather data, and computational chemistry. The testbed was leveraged to create a Data Lake of weather data for the Pacific Rim Application and Grid Middleware Assembly (PRAGMA). The testbed also provided FAIR compliant workflow descriptions within the Science and Application Grid (SEAGrid). 

To meet the third goal of the project, which included educating the data sharing and cyberinfrastructure communities, the project participated in more than a dozen in-person and remote information and training sessions, including events at PRAGMA, the Research Data Alliance (RDA), Practice and Experience in Academic Research Computing (PEARC), the Science Gateway Community Institute (SGCI) annual conference, and eXtreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) symposiums.

The Intellectual Merit of the ERPID testbed was the creation of a fully-realized PID-Centric data management infrastructure which allowed the FAIR principles to be applied to existing and future data repositories. The ERPID implementation was flexible enough to be used across diverse scientific disciplines and created new data management possibilities for researchers wishing to align their research data with the FAIR principles. The ERPID project was the subject of more than 20 publications and presentations during the lifetime of the grant award. 

The Broader Impact of the ERPID project was the community adoption of the FAIR principles and the movement of the research community toward the adoption of both FAIR and the DOA. International research groups are adopting both the cyberinfrastructure components and the principles first implemented within the ERPID testbed. These implementations include testbeds and projects in climate modeling, material science, specimen collections, language translations, and biomedical (https://zenodo.org/record/5872645). 

Overall the ERPID project and testbed showed how the practical operation of a few low-overhead data services could create the necessary cyberinfrastructure for real-world application of the FAIR data principles. Conforming to the FAIR principles adds additional value by creating research data that is more discoverable, machine-actionable, and ultimately reusable.
